Did you know that thaumatrope is an optical toy that was popular in the 19th century? A disk with a picture on each side is attached to two pieces of string. Today, in Mrs. Simmons' 7th-grade science class, her students applied their process knowledge of the scientific method to make and interpret observations in an interactive lab. She showed her students that raisins naturally sink to the bottom of the soda water when you first drop them in. But then, carbon dioxide (CO2) molecules start to rise and escape the water because they are much less dense than the water. When there are enough gas bubbles stuck to the raisins' wrinkles, it changes the buoyancy of the raisin and allows the raisin “to dance” or float to the surface. Once the bubbles pop at the surface, the raisin drops back down to the bottom!

They communicated their results and practiced their writing skills by completing lab reports about the science behind what they saw happening on their screens and in the video that Mrs. Simmons shared: #WhereTeachingStillMatters

#EarthDay2020 is coming to an end, but that doesn’t mean that we can’t show our environment some love by recycling, being conscious of our energy usage, and finding ways to limit our carbon footprint, every day.

To bring awareness to Earth Day and how we can better care for our planet, PA Distance teachers did (and are doing) the following with their students:

🌎 Mrs. Marinzel had her kindergarten classes read an Earth Day story and the Scholastic weekly reader.
